message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pelvic ring fracture can cause impingement of the femoral nerve, which innervates the adductors of the hip, resulting in impaired adduction of the hip. Impaired hip extension would be more likely with injury to the gluteal muscles, while impaired knee extension and sensory deficit of the dorsal foot would suggest injury to the sciatic nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The affected area is the proximal medial thigh, which is innervated by the obturator nerve that controls adduction of the hip. Therefore, impaired adduction of the hip is the most likely finding. None of the other options correspond with the innervation of the affected area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pelvic ring fracture may compress the obturator nerve, which supplies the adductor muscles of the thigh. Impaired adduction of the hip is a common finding in obturator nerve injury. The other options are not typically associated with this type of injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest an injury to the posterior branch of the obturator nerve, which is responsible for adduction of the hip. None of the other options match the symptoms presented by the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fracture likely involves the acetabulum and disrupts the obturator nerve that passes through the obturator foramen, leading to impaired adduction of the hip. None of the other options are directly related to the injury described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pelvic ring fracture can cause damage to the obturator nerve, which would result in impaired adduction of the hip. Sensory deficit of the dorsal foot would suggest damage to the L4 nerve root. Impaired hip extension would suggest damage to the sciatic nerve. Impaired extension of the knee would suggest damage to the femoral nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with numbness along the right thigh, indicating a possible compression of the femoral or obturator nerve. Impaired adduction of the hip is a sign of femoral or obturator nerve injury, which is consistent with the patient’s symptoms and pelvic ring fracture. The other options are not consistent with the patient’s presenting symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a displaced pelvic ring fracture, which can lead to injury to the femoral nerve, resulting in impaired adduction of the hip. Sensory deficit of the dorsal foot is associated with injury to the sciatic nerve, and impaired hip extension and extension of the knee are associated with injury to the femoral nerve.

We refer to anatomy textbooks for help. The patient has a displaced pelvic ring fracture, which is likely to affect the muscles involved in adduction of the hip such as the adductor longus, adductor brevis, and adductor magnus. This is consistent with the decrease in sensation to light touch over a small area of the proximal medial thigh, which is the area innervated by the obturator nerve that runs along the adductor muscles. The other options are not typically affected by pelvic ring fractures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with numbness along the right thigh, which suggests involvement of the femoral nerve. This nerve is responsible for hip adduction, so impaired adduction of the hip is the most likely finding. Sensory deficit of the dorsal foot is associated with the peroneal nerve and impaired hip extension and knee extension are associated with the sciatic nerve.
